conclusion: To calculate the distance traveled by the car within 60 seconds, break the problem into three time intervals based on the acceleration graph.
Acceleration graph shows changes over time with intervals at 10, 30, and 60 seconds.
Use kinematic equations for each interval.
Interval 1: 0 to 10 seconds, initial velocity u1 = 0 m/s, acceleration a1 = 2 m/s², time t1 = 10 seconds.
Calculate distance s1 using kinematic equation: s1 = 0 × 10 + 1/2 × 2 × 10² = 100 meters.
Final velocity at end of interval 1: v1 = 0 + 2 × 10 = 20 m/s.
Interval 2: 10 to 30 seconds, initial velocity u2 = v1 = 20 m/s, acceleration a2 = 0 m/s², time t2 = 20 seconds.
Calculate distance s2 using kinematic equation: s2 = 20 × 20 + 1/2 × 0 × 20² = 400 meters.
Final velocity at end of interval 2 remains v2 = 20 m/s.
Interval 3: 30 to 60 seconds, initial velocity u3 = v2 = 20 m/s, acceleration a3 = -1 m/s², time t3 = 30 seconds.
Calculate distance s3 using kinematic equation: s3 = 20 × 30 + 1/2 × (-1) × 30² = 150 meters.
Final velocity at end of interval 3: v3 = 20 - 1 × 30 = -10 m/s.
Total distance traveled: s_total = s1 + s2 + s3 = 100 + 400 + 150 = 650 meters.
The car travels a total distance of 650 meters within these 60 seconds.
